BJP MP Yogi Adityanath may be facing flak at home, with even the Shiv Sena reprimanding him for advising Bollywood superstar Shah Rukh Khan to relocate to Pakistan, but the firebrand MP has received unlikely praise from Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif for giving a fillip to Pakistan’s ailing tourism sector.

“One on hand, we are struggling to get even the Zimbabwe cricket team to tour our country,” Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif said, eyes welling with tears, “and here Yogi sahab is urging icons like Shah Rukh and intellectual celebrities participating in Award Wapasi to go to Pakistan. We really appreciate Yogi sahab’s efforts in shoring up Pakistan’s image as a land of peace and harmony, perhaps even liberalism.”

“We hope he keeps up with his ‘Go to Pakistan’ rant so that many more Indian liberals can experience the legendary warmth and hospitality of Pakistanis,” Sharif added. Accordingly, the Pakistan government has decided to appoint Yogi Adityanath as the unofficial brand ambassador for Pakistan tourism.

And it’s not just Pakistan’s tourism sector that will get a fillip. A Pakistan MP told The UnReal Times, ”If all these intellectuals leave India and come to Pakistan, the overall literacy rates of the country will increase which will further strengthen our relations with USA as they will think that we are actually using their humanitarian aid for education and not for manufacturing canons and bullets!”

In a related development, Rajdeep Sardesai who has many friends in Oxford, has requested ”Go to Pakistan!” be included as a severe form of abuse in the Oxford dictionary.
column4: Pak govt nominates Yogi Adityanath as brand ambassador for Pakistan tourism

column3:
This story is from October 25, 2019

Prime Minister Narendra Modi and BJP president Amit Shah greeting supporters at party headquarters after the r... Read More

Haryana

Maharashtra

Jharkhand

Download The Times of India News App for Latest Politics News

Subscribe Start Your Daily Mornings with Times of India Newspaper! Order Now

NEW DELHI: The results of Maharashtra and Haryana assembly elections should make BJP worry about its prospects in Jharkhand. The ruling party may be forced to tweak its strategy when Jharkhand goes to polls in December.The reason for BJP’s worry may originate from the fact that Jharkhand shares some common political situations with Maharashtra and Haryana which went to polls on October 21.After the 2014 Lok Sabha elections, when the Narendra Modi government came to power, while Maharashtra and Haryana were the first two states to go to polls in October, Jharkhand had faced elections in December the same year.Second, riding on Modi wave, BJP won elections in Jharkhand too.Third, for the first time, Modi and BJP president Amit Shah experimented with social engineering in the three states. In all the three states, BJP installed unconventional chief ministers.Devendra Fadnavis, a Brahmin, took over as the chief minister of Maharashtra which is dominated politically by Marathas. Similarly, Manohar Lal Khattar, a Punjabi, took over the reins of the state where Jats have always dominated the politics.After being carved out as a separate state from Bihar in 2000, tribal-dominated Jharkhand had seen five chief ministers - Babulal Marandi, Arjun Munda, Shibu Soren, Madhu Koda, Hemant Soren. All these five leaders belong to the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category.However, after the 2014 Jharkhand assembly election, BJP chose non-tribal Raghubar Das to head the state.Das comes from the OBC category. He is a teli - a caste which was traditionally engaged in the profession of oil-pressing - became the first non-tribal leader to become the chief minister of the state.Thursday’s results in Maharashtra and Jharkhand were below BJP’s expectations. It had hoped to win 75 of the 90 seats in Haryana and 145 of the 288 seats in Maharashtra.Prime Minister Narendra Modi and BJP president Amit Shah, in order to offset the damage due to caste equations besides economic slowdown, joblessness and agrarian distress in both the states, depended heavily on nationalistic issues in their campaign.The two harped on nullification of Articles 370 and 35A changing the status of Jammu and Kashmir. They talked of the 2016 surgical strikes and air strikes in February in retaliation to Pulwama terror attack. They also discussed banning instant triple talaq.Amit Shah promised to implement National Register of Citizens (NRC) on the national level by 2024.However, caste politics played a major part in checking BJP’s juggernaut.The BJP had to bear the brunt of going against the caste equations in Haryana and Maharashtra - in fact more in Haryana than in Maharashtra.Haryana was sharply divided between Jats and non-Jats. The Jats went against BJP which kept the party from touching the majority mark of 46 seats.On the other hand, a weakened Congress, which was hardly expected to cross even the double digit, became the second largest party by winning 31 seats. The credit goes to the party installing former chief minister Bhupinder Hooda , a Jat, just before the elections.The other Jat-led party - Jannayak Janata Party (JJP) headed by Dushyant Chautala - was the third largest party winning 10 seats.Similarly, going against the tide of caste proved challenging for BJP in Maharashtra.NCP supremo Sharad Pawar , who is considered as the tallest Maratha leader, weaned away the community members.It did not help BJP much even though it went out of its way to woo the Marathas. Prime Minister Narendra Modi and BJP president Amit Shah invoked Marathas’ tallest and historical icon Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in several of their election rallies in the state.But they could not control the damage completely.As in Haryana and Maharashtra, BJP is likely to face the trouble of the voters getting divided between tribal and non-tribal supporters.The opposition parties, particularly tribal-dominated and former chief minister Shibu Soren-led Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM), Congress and Lalu Prasad’s RJD will try their best to wean away the tribal voters from BJP.By the time Jharkhand elections are held in December, nullification of Article 370 and banning instant triple talaq will get older and, therefore, lose their sheen.BJP is likely to change its discourse in Jharkhand to overcome the sentiments against installing a non-tribal as CM, economic slowdown, joblessness and farmers’ distress.Besides tribal identity, joblessness is likely to become a major election issue in Jharkhand which has several industrial towns such as Jamshedpur and Bokaro. Several factories are facing the impact of economic recession and have been forced to either shut down or curtail shifts.Raking up nationalistic issues may have controlled some damage to the BJP governments in Maharashtra and Haryana. But it may not be enough to surmount the challenges in Jharkhand.
column4: Election results 2019: Why Maharashtra, Haryana outcome poses risk for BJP in Jharkhand

column3:
This story is from October 18, 2019

Dushyanat Chautala

Download The Times of India News App for Latest Politics News

Subscribe Start Your Daily Mornings with Times of India Newspaper! Order Now

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab and Haryana high court has sought the Union government and the state of Haryana’s response on a plea filed by Jannayak Janata Party (JJP) leader Dushyant Chautala , seeking directions to provide him a security cover through a central security agency. In his petition, Dushyant has informed HC about threat to his life from an international gang.When the matter came up for hearing before Justice Sanjay Kumar of HC on Thursday, additional solicitor general of India Satya Pal Jain appeared on behalf of the ministry of home affairs (MHA) and told the HC that government is assessing the perception of threat as claimed by Dushyant. Jain further informed that it is a state subject and Centre provides security only in those cases where the perception of threat is very high. He, however, said that matter is under examination of central agency.The Haryana government counsel informed the court that already an additional security personnell has been provided to Dushyant after his complaint. However, the petitioner’s counsel informed that as gunmen cannot accompany Dushyant in the chopper, no security personnel has been provided to him when he lands in any area for campaigning in assembly polls.During hearing, Justice Kumar orally asked the state government to examine if any security personnel can be provided to him at the place where his chopper lands.HC has now adjourned the hearing of the case for Friday, asking the counsels for Union and state government to seek instructions from the respective governments on the issue.In his plea filed through advocate Naresh Shekhawat, the former Hisar MP, who is now contesting assembly polls from Uchana assembly seat, claimed to have received a call from a person calling from Dubai. According to the petition, he has been threatened not to campaign vigorously in the state assembly elections, else he would face dire consequences. According to Dushyant, the man who allegedly threatened him claimed that he was a member of an international gang. After Dushyant’s complaint, an FIR has also been registered in this regard by Jind district police.
column4: High court asks Centre, Haryana government to respond to Dushyant Chautala’s plea for security

column3:
With the race to the Rashtrapathi Bhavan entering the final phase, Sonia Gandhi called for a crucial meeting at her 10 Janpath residence with Dr. Manmonhan Singh, Pranab Mukherjee, Rahul Gandhi and West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee. What happened in this crucial meeting? The UnReal Times brings you the details.

Seen sitting at the head of the table in a mammoth chair is Sonia Gandhi in a regal posture. Across the table at the other end, Mamata Banerjee is seen slouching on her chair, noisily filing her fingernails. Pranab Mukherjee and Rahul Gandhi are sitting on either side of Sonia Gandhi whereas Dr. Manmohan Singh is sitting midway on one side of the table throwing nervous glances at Sonia Gandhi and Mamata Banerjee in turns. Sonia’s bodyguards and some Congress workers are seen standing at a distance of a few feet around the table in a circle.

Sonia Gandhi: Okay, so what are our options now?

Manmohan Singh: Madam, first there is PA Sangma.

Sonia Gandhi: That Nepali?!? No way will I make a foreigner the President of India!

Manmohan Singh: But Madam, Sangma ji is not a foreigner. He is from Meghalaya. Besides you also… (Sonia turns to glare at Dr. Singh)

Manmohan Singh: Er.. right Madam, we cannot have a Nepali as the President.

Sonia Gandhi: Glad you agree. So who else?

Manmohan Singh (nervously smiles at Mamata Banerjee): Er.. Didi had a suggestion for the Presidential candidate as well. Didi, if you will tell Madam .

Mamata Banerjee (looks up at Sonia): Vuee vuant Shomnath Bonorjee ash Preshidunt.

Sonia stares back blankly at Mamata for a second, then turns to Pranab Mukherjee quizzically

Pranab Mukherjee: Wot shee meansh ish Shomnath Bonorjee kud bhee a ghud condidate.

Sonia stares blankly at Pranab, then turns to Dr. Singh

Manmohan Singh: Somanth Chatterjee Madam.

Sonia Gandhi: Ah I see. Well, what can I say? Obviously I cannot trash the suggestion instantly seeing that it comes from Didi. But let’s keep it in our consideration set, shall we?

At that point the meeting is interrupted by a loud knock at the door.

Voice outside: Alak niranjan! Kya is Baba ko ghar se kuch milega?

Sonia Gandhi: Whats this noise? Who’s that?

Pranab Mukherjee: Shome poor Baba, Madam, letsh ignore him.

Sonia Gandhi: Hmm. So as I was saying…

Voice outside: Alak Niranjan! Kya is Baba ko ghar se kuch milega?

Sonia Gandhi (irritated): Uff, what rubbish yaa! Rahul, go find out who it is and what he wants

(Rahul walks to the door and opens it to find Baba Ramdev standing there with outstretched arms. “Come to Baba,” he says with a smile)

Rahul Gandhi: Mummy, its Baba Ramdev. He wants a hug and some black money from abroad.

Sonia Gandhi (impatiently): Well, hug him, and ask him to ‘aage badho‘ for black money.

Rahul Gandhi does so and Baba Ramdev moves on. The meeting continues.

Sonia Gandhi: Okay. Let’s continue. Who else?

Manmohan Singh: Pranab da Madam. Given his distinguished career, and the fact that he has no more chance to be the PM thanks to the performance of my bumbling government, he deserves to be made the President Madam.

Sonia Gandhi: Hmm. I hear you Manmohan ji. But…

Manmohan Singh: Yes Madam?

Sonia Gandhi (sighs deeply): Rajiv ji used to say Pranab da will make a lousy President. In 1984, after Indira ji’s assassination when Rajiv ji asked Pranab da on who should be the PM, he said the seniormost Congress leader should be the PM.

At this, there’s a collective gasp in the room, as everyone turns to look at Pranabda. After a brief silence…

Pranabda (sniffs softly): Madam, I am so shorry! That was a long time ago. I wash young and foolish! I have learnt my leshon now Madam. I’ll never say crap like that again! Boo hoo! (Slams his head on the table and sobs loudly)

Sonia Gandhi: Okay Pranab da, let’s try this again. After the 2014 elections, if there’s a hung parliament and there’s no clear winner, who will become the Prime Minister?

Pranabda (immediately): Rahul, Madam.

Everybody claps.

Sonia Gandhi (satisfied): Okay, he’s good to go. I hereby announce Pranab da as our Presidential candidate.

After applauding, hugging and back-slapping a teary-eyed but happy Pranab da, the participants file out of the room one by one, led by their charismatic leader.
column4: REVEALED: How UPA under Sonia Gandhi’s leadership finalized the Presidential Candidate

column3:
The Aam Aadmi Party chief Arvind Kejriwal made a sensational revelation today that Lord Shiva is actually an AAP supporter. A study conducted by AAP’s internal committee confirmed this claim.

Addressing a press conference, the AAP supremo said, “We were always aware of our huge following across the globe but it came as a pleasant surprise to learn that even Lord Shiva has been supporting our party ever since its inception.”

“We concluded this after studying the report which suggested that we have an identical approach to solve critical issues like Lord Shiva. For example, Lord Shiva consumed poison to save the universe just like what our Bhagwant Mann is doing to save the youth of Punjab.”

“But how?” we sought a clarification.

“He is on a mission to drink every single drop of alcohol to control rising alcoholism, and if we come to power, we will employ similar measures to curb the menace of drug abuse as well in Punjab.”

“But isn’t AAP just a 4-year-old party?”

To this he said, “Yes, AAP as a party is relatively new in Indian politics but its ideologies are not. People have been following the values of AAP since time immemorial.”

Emphasizing on Lord Shiva’s political inclination, he said, ““Lord Shiva is regarded as limitless, transcendent, unchanging and formless. Who else other than an AAP supporter could possess these qualities? Hence, Shiva is an AAP supporter.”

This news has given AAP’s election campaign in Punjab, Canada, and Goa a new lease of life and people are attending their rallies and visiting AAP offices across the country in numbers to have a glimpse of the party workers. Even experts are predicting them to sweep all seats in the upcoming assembly elections.

Meanwhile, fresh evidences are emerging from different parts of the world that lend credence to the notion that AAP’s values and ideologies were followed in ancient times as well. During an excavation, archeologists have found Aam Aadmi caps and brooms at the site of Mohenjo Daro, which indicates the presence of AAP party workers during Indus Valley Civilization. They have also found WiFi towers under the ground, which they believe were fully functional during that period.

This development, however, has forced Ashutosh Gwarikar to defer the release date of his movie Mohenjo Daro, as he will now have to re-shoot part of the movie to portray AAP’s contributions in Mohenjo Daro and its way of life.
column4: “Lord Shiva drank poison to save the universe, which confirms he is an AAP supporter” : Kejriwal

column3:
Eminent movie reviewer and trade analyst Taran Adarsh announced his retirement today, bringing to an end a commendable career spanning decades. An emotional Adarsh cited that the drastic increase in the number of people switching over to the movie reviews of Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal was the main reason behind his retirement.

“It was all going fine. Even the greatest of movie reviewers couldn’t come near my shadow. But the onslaught of Arvindji was too much to handle. Many people across the country began to follow his movie reviews and no one was paying heed to my insightful critiques. His latest review of Drishyam was the nail in the coffin. I just knew instinctively, that I had to stop right there and quit honorably. So that’s what I did,” Adarsh told The UnReal Times.

“I heard from sources that the CM has a lot more movies lined up – Rogue Nation being the next one. He’s planning to watch them first day first show itself, I’ve heard. I sometimes watch the matinee show or even the night show, especially for movies that are bound to be real lousy. And Sajid Khan movies tho, I don’t watch at all. But Arvindji is on the job every time. I simply couldn’t have gone on,” Adarsh added.

Sources added that the Delhi CM’s movie reviews have amazed PM Narendra Modi too. “Yaar, this guy goes to movies more frequently than I go on foreign tours! I’ve some catching up to do,” the PM apparently said.

When asked what Adarsh thought of his enviable career, the bespectacled analyst said, “Well, what else can I say? It was good while it lasted. I would give my career nothing less than 4.5 stars.”
column4: Taran Adarsh announces retirement after people increasingly switch to Arvind Kejriwal’s movie reviews

column3:
